title: Zimbabwe: Military, Police, Universities Keep the Dollars Coming for Mugabe
text:
Zimbabwe: Govt to Assume RBZ's U.S $1,4 Billion Debt 
They now appear to have rushed in with State supplied funds to save the First Family's struggling dairy business. 
Gushungo Dairies manager, Albert Nhari inadvertently, let the cat out of the bag recently when he told dignitaries at the sprawling farming compound in Mazowe that the veteran leader was indebted to the country's securocrats for helping keep the business afloat. 
"I must also thank police Commissioner General Augustine Chihuri as well as army General Constantine Chiwenga," said Nhari. 
"Their organisations continued to support us buying our products even when nobody was willing to be associated with anything to do with President Mugabe and Zanu PF. 
"They (army and ZRP) did not stop doing business with us even when we were under severe sanction that almost brought the economy down." 
Nhari also revealed that his company does business with schools, colleges and universities. Mugabe is the chancellor of all state universities. 
The farm manager's revelations come at a time the opposition MDC-T is mulling a boycott of Zanu PF-linked businesses to increase pressure on the 91-year-old leader who refuses to step down. 
Although he was re-elected for another five year term in 2013, the MDC-T insists Mugabe, yet again, cheated his way to victory. Other critics say, at 91,Mugabe may have the will but not the energy to take the country out of its present mire. 
Zanu PF has rejected calls by the MDCs for electoral reforms, but MDC-T secretary general Douglas Mwonzora told NewZimbabwe.com recently that the veteran leader would have no choice but oblige before year-end. 
While details about the business boycott remain sketchy, senior MDC-T officials said they were in putting together the final stages of a plan to target Mugabe and Zanu PF businesses. 
"There is going to be something big that could bring Mugabe to his knees," a national executive member of the MDC-T told NewZimbabwe.com. 
"It will be massive, we need to withdraw our cash from Mugabe. Zimbabweans cannot be seen to be supporting their own misery. 
"The (party) leadership will make an announcement very soon." Zimbabwe
